attributes.alt: Cover for Rabbit Moon by Jean Kim. The cover art shows a rabbit wearing a space helmet flying in space from the moon and holding onto a big star.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about the alphabet (letters
), engage children with song and rhymes, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What wonderful things does Rabbit do?
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Understand conventions of print, including end punctuation.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Invite children to recognize and make the sounds of the letters
Show children how to make an insect for the letter
What do we do during the day and at night?
Does the book you are reading take place during the day or night? How do you know?
What can you do at night? Pretend it is nighttime and show what you do.
How many stars do you think there are in a nighttime sky? Show 10 stars with counters.
What do you think about when see a star? Write about it.
Draw a picture of what you do at night.
What letter do you hear at the beginning of
Can you make a bed for the animals to sleep in at night?

Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.

Invite children to use materials to make wishing stars with black paper stars and dots.
Ask children to respond to a signal and then clean up by sorting leftover materials onto two plates.
What do we do during the day and at night?
Show the part of the book you are reading that shows the sun, moon, or stars.
Show something you do during the daytime.
Draw a picture of children playing during the daytime. Count how many children you drew.
When is a time you should think before you speak?
Make a picture of yourself doing something you like to do during the day.
do you see in the word sunshine? Make an

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build science background and introduce a new vocabulary word
What do the animals see in the nighttime sky?
Check understanding, and differentiate as needed.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Understand conventions of print, including end punctuation and case.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Show children pictures of three different moon shapes—full, half, and crescent.
Provides three shapes for children to use to make nighttime moon scenes.
What do we do during the day and at night?
Is your book make-believe or real? How do you know?
Pretend you are the raccoon and you are making a wish. What will you wish for?
Why is it important to learn about the sun, moon, and stars?
What if you could invite Rabbit to play with you? Write about what you would do together.
What colors would you use to paint a picture of the daytime sky?
Find those Magnetic Letters and write the word.
Sometimes people use a telescope to look at the stars. How can you build a make-believe telescope?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Daytime Nighttime. On the left side is the word Daytime written on the sun. Below it are pictures that say: It's daytime in the mountains; It's daytime in the country; It's daytime in the city. On the right  side of the chart is the word Nighttime written over a starry sky. Below it are pictures that say: It's nighttime in the mountains; It's nighttime in the country; It's nighttime in the city.
Cover for Rabbit Moon by Jean Kim. The cover art shows a rabbit wearing a space helmet flying in space from the moon and holding onto a big star.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to talk about day and night and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts,
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question:
What do we do during the day and at night?
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Discuss what people see in a daytime sky.
Invite children to use crayons and cotton balls to make daytime sky scenes.
Talk about what the clouds look like.
What do we do during the day and at night?
Compare the book you are reading to today’s Big Chart.
Think about visiting the Moon. What would you want to see when you look at the Earth?
Compare the Sun and Moon. How are they alike? How are they different?
Think about the Rabbit in the  Moon. Write a note to tell him why you like him.
Use materials to make a fancy moon.

Make a place for Rabbit to sleep when he comes to Earth.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to sing a song about stars, talk about stars, and review vocabulary
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What might you see in the sky at night?
Read and retell interactively for engagement and imagination.
Share and repeat the details in a text.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
Write some things you know about day and night.
Save children’s work to display next week.

Pretend you are playing outside on a sunny day and suddenly it gets cloudy and rains. Show what you will do next.

Write about the part you liked best.
Create a picture that you could add to the book
Can you read an Alphabet Book with a friend? Share Alphabet Books Nn, Ii, Cc.
Build a place for Rabbit to play when he comes to Earth.
